title: لَا سِيَّمَا
description: Learn about the particle لَا سِيَّمَا meaning 'especially' - its grammatical analysis, various case options for the noun after it, and usage in classical Arabic.

notes.title: What is لَا سِيَّمَا?
content: لَا سِيَّمَا is a compound expression meaning 'especially,' 'particularly,' or 'above all.' It is used to single out one member of a group as the most notable or important example.

The expression comes from: لَا (negation) + سِيَّ (equal/like) + مَا (which can be various types). The literal meaning is 'there is no equal, especially...' implying the mentioned item is exceptional.
keyPoints: Singles out an exceptional member of a group
لَا نَافِيَةٌ لِلْجِنْسِ: لَا of categorical negation

examples.english: I love fruits, especially apples

examples.arabic: يَنْبَغِي احْتِرَامُ الْكِبَارِ وَلَا سِيَّمَا الْوَالِدَيْنِ
examples.english: One should respect elders, especially parents

examples.arabic: أَقْرَأُ الْكُتُبَ وَلَا سِيَّمَا كُتُبُ الْعِلْمِ
examples.english: I read books, especially books of knowledge
I visited cities, especially Mecca

notes.title: Grammatical Analysis of لَا سِيَّمَا
content: The grammatical analysis of لَا سِيَّمَا is complex and debated among grammarians. The standard analysis: لَا is لا النافية للجنس (categorical negation), سِيَّ is its اسم (subject) in the منصوب state, and مَا can be analyzed differently.
The خبر of لَا is محذوف (deleted), understood as مَوْجُودٌ (existing). So 'لا سيّ' means 'there is no equal' - negating that anything equals what follows.

examples.arabic: لَا سِيَّمَا: لا نافية للجنس، سِيَّ اسمها منصوب
examples.english: Standard i'rab: لَا of categorical negation, سِيَّ its subject
Deleted predicate estimated as: 'existing'
Meaning: 'no equal exists'
سِيَّ is in construct with what follows

notes.title: The مَا in لَا سِيَّمَا
content: The مَا in لَا سِيَّمَا can be analyzed in three ways, each affecting the case of the following noun: 1) مَا موصولة (relative 'what'), 2) مَا نكرة موصوفة (indefinite 'something'), 3) مَا زائدة (extra particle).
These different analyses allow for flexibility in the case of the noun that follows, making لَا سِيَّمَا unique among Arabic expressions.

examples.english: As relative: 'especially that which...'

examples.arabic: مَا نكرة: لا سِيَّ شَيْءٍ هُوَ...
examples.english: As indefinite: 'especially something that is...'
As extra: direct construct to noun
All three analyses are valid

notes.title: Case Options After لَا سِيَّمَا
content: The noun after لَا سِيَّمَا can take three cases: 1) رَفْع (nominative) - treating it as خبر of a deleted مبتدأ (هُوَ), 2) جَرّ (genitive) - treating it as مضاف إليه to سِيَّ, 3) نَصْب (accusative) - treating مَا as زائدة and the noun as تمييز or مفعول.
All three cases are acceptable in classical Arabic, though رَفْع and جَرّ are most common. This flexibility is unique to لَا سِيَّمَا.
keyPoints: رَفْع: noun is خبر for deleted هُوَ
جَرّ: noun is مضاف إليه to سِيَّ
نَصْب: noun is تمييز or مفعول

examples.english: Especially Zayd (nominative - as خبر)
Especially Zayd (genitive - as مضاف إليه)
Especially Zayd (accusative - as تمييز)
I love scholars, especially al-Shafi'i (all three possible)

notes.title: Usage Patterns
content: لَا سِيَّمَا typically follows a general statement and introduces a specific, highlighted example. It can be preceded by وَ (and) for emphasis: وَلَا سِيَّمَا.
When followed by a sentence (جملة) rather than a single noun, the sentence functions as صلة الموصول if مَا is relative, or صفة if مَا is indefinite. Common pattern: لَا سِيَّمَا إِذَا/إِنْ...
keyPoints: Often preceded by وَ: وَلَا سِيَّمَا
Can be followed by sentence: لَا سِيَّمَا إِذَا...

examples.arabic: أُحِبُّ الْعَمَلَ وَلَا سِيَّمَا إِذَا كَانَ لِوَجْهِ اللهِ
examples.english: I love work, especially if it is for Allah's sake

examples.arabic: الصَّبْرُ مَحْمُودٌ لَا سِيَّمَا عِنْدَ الْمُصِيبَةِ
examples.english: Patience is praiseworthy, especially during calamity

examples.arabic: يَحْسُنُ الصَّمْتُ وَلَا سِيَّمَا فِي مَجْلِسِ الْعِلْمِ
examples.english: Silence is good, especially in a gathering of knowledge

examples.arabic: اِقْرَأِ الْكُتُبَ وَلَا سِيَّمَا مَا يَنْفَعُكَ
examples.english: Read books, especially what benefits you

notes.title: Classical Examples and Variants
content: لَا سِيَّمَا appears frequently in classical texts, hadith, and scholarly works. Some grammarians also accept the shortened form سِيَّمَا (without لَا) in poetry and some dialects.

The expression demonstrates the flexibility of classical Arabic grammar - one phrase with multiple valid analyses, all preserving the same meaning. This is a hallmark of Arabic's rich grammatical tradition.
keyPoints: Common in classical texts and hadith
سِيَّمَا alone sometimes used in poetry

examples.english: The best of you is the best to his family, especially parents

examples.arabic: الْعِلْمُ نَافِعٌ لَا سِيَّمَا عِلْمُ الشَّرِيعَةِ
examples.english: Knowledge is beneficial, especially knowledge of Shariah
He praised poets, especially al-Mutanabbi

examples.arabic: زُرِ الْعُلَمَاءَ سِيَّمَا مَنْ كَانَ زَاهِدًا
examples.english: Visit scholars, especially those who are ascetic (poetry)

Equal, like, similar (the root of سِيَّمَا)
